Tera Ice cranks up the power of Sneasel's strongest STAB move to ice out bulkier Pokemon such as Tera Fairy Nasty Plot Mesprit and Weezing. Tera Ice also boosts Sneasel's priority to more effectively pick off Jolteon, Oricorio-F, and Whimsicott.

Choice Band Sneasel has great immediate damage output, quickly cutting through teams with Triple Axel and making progress with Knock Off. Choice Band Sneasel's ability to lure in and remove Leftovers from Regirock makes it a great enabler to offensive Pokemon that struggle against it such as Charizard, Snorlax, and Oricorio-F, and it functions similarly against Orthworm to support Mesprit and Whimsicott. Knock Off removing Heavy-Duty Boots from foes creates excellent synergy with entry hazard setting Pokemon such as Sandslash and Orthworm. Choice Band Sneasel is vulnerable to being worn down by entry hazards, particularly Stealth Rock, so hazard removers like Sandslash and Lurantis are critical to maximizing Sneasel's offensive presence. Defensive pivots like Lanturn and Mesprit can bring Sneasel in safely in spite of its poor bulk and vulnerable defensive typing. While Sneasel resists Shadow Sneak and Sucker Punch from foes like Muk and Hitmontop, its frailty leaves it prone to strong and super effective priority users; Sandaconda and Weezing can check Passimian and Hisuian Sneasel for Sneasel. Choice Band Sneasel is fast but still struggles with revenge killers like Passimian, Choice Specs, and Choice Scarf Typhlosion, which can be respectively handled by teammates like Orthworm, Weezing, and Regirock.

Sneasel-Hisui.overview: Hisuian Sneasel is a powerful and versatile threat in ZU, leveraging its excellent Speed tier and powerful STAB attacks to great effect. Not much in the metagame can withstand its potent Close Combat and Gunk Shot combination, and those that can, like Mesprit and Mismagius, are threatened by Throat Chop. With Switcheroo to disrupt foes that otherwise give it issues, like Iron Defense Regirock, Hisuian Sneasel has the tools to position itself to wreak havoc. Swords Dance Hisuian Sneasel can utilize Trailblaze to become a devastatingly fast and powerful late-game cleaner. It does, however, have subpar bulk without Eviolite and can struggle at times to pick up KOs against premiere walls like Dipplin and Regirock if they use Terastallization. Hisuian Sneasel's weaknesses to common types like Flying, Ground, and Psychic mean it struggles to hit the field safely and use its offensive traits to great success against notable foes like Charizard, Sandslash, and offensive Mesprit.
Sneasel-Hisui.comments:
Other Options

Hisuian Sneasel has access to Toxic Spikes, which can cause disruption without needing to swap items with Switcheroo. Toxic, similarly, can be used to reliably status checks Hisuian Sneasel can't normally get past, such as Spiritomb. Taunt can be used to stop slower setup sweepers like Mesprit or prevent recovery attempts from foes like Dipplin and Oricorio formes, though it is difficult to use given how frail Hisuian Sneasel is.

Checks and Counters

Psychic-types: Mesprit is a notable Hisuian Sneasel check with the bulk to withstand its powerful attacks and the ability to threaten it with an OHKO back. Farigiraf is similarly difficult for it to deal with.

Ghost-types: Spiritomb can sponge Hisuian Sneasel's attacks and threaten it back with Psyshock. Mismagius and Tera Ghost users like Magneton can also use their brute power to threaten an OHKO against it.

Faster Revenge Killers and Wallbreakers: Despite its excellent Speed tier, non-Choice Scarf Hisuian Sneasel is slower than common Choice Scarf users like Passimian and Mesprit, which can threaten it immensely with Earthquake and Psychic Noise, respectively. Likewise, Choice Specs Jolteon is able to pick Hisuian Sneasel off cleanly with Thunderbolt.

Poison-types: Weezing can reliably sponge attacks from Hisuian Sneasel and threaten to disrupt it with Will-O-Wisp. Muk is less reliable as a check but can nail it with Zen Headbutt after tanking an attack. Tera Poison Dipplin can stonewall Hisuian Sneasel with Sticky Hold to prevent disruption from Switcheroo and the ability to phaze it with Dragon Tail to stop setup attempts. Likewise, Tera Poison Regirock can use IronPress against Hisuian Sneasel to great effect, threatening to reverse sweep after just one boost.

Swords Dance.description:
Swords Dance Hisuian Sneasel is a great setup sweeper in the ZU metagame, capable of blowing through teams as a late-game sweeper thanks to its strong STAB moves and good typing. Throat Chop provides the coverage to hit foes like Mesprit and Muk hard, preventing the former from hitting it back with Psychic Noise; Trailblaze, alternatively, can allow Hisuian Sneasel to outpace the entire metagame after one boost to more consistently threaten a sweep. Hitmontop. Tera Dark can stop Psychic-type attacks from halting a sweep, as well as boost Throat Chop tremendously, securing an OHKO on offensive Mesprit after a Swords Dance. Tera Dark also prevents niche Prankster users like Sableye from disrupting a potential sweep. Tera Grass, meanwhile, flips the weakness to Ground and allows Hisuian Sneasel to set up against foes like Sandslash.

With its prolific Speed tier and snowballing ability, Swords Dance Hisuian Sneasel is a great fit on bulky offense and offense teams alike. Teammates that can provide entry hazards to chip down walls like Dipplin and Sandslash are much appreciated; on offensive teams, Primeape is a great lead, while on bulky offense teams, Mesprit and Orthworm provide Hisuian Sneasel hazards and reliable defensive pivots, if needed. Teammates that can lure in foes like Arboliva and Dipplin that Hisuian Sneasel can set up against include VoltTurn users like Magneton and Mesprit. Jolteon is another notable teammate, capable of setting up for its own sweep and flexibly pivoting into Hisuian Sneasel. Other setup sweepers like Mesprit, Mismagius, and Oricorio are great teammates, similarly helping break the opposition down for Hisuian Sneasel or taking advantage of worn down foes themselves to clean late-game. Vikavolt is a powerful support option, helping check Mesprit and providing Sticky Web so Hisuian Sneasel can outpace Choice Scarf users like Passimian and Mesprit. Other physical wallbreakers that can wear down shared checks include Virizion, which can help break down foes like Sandaconda and Sandslash that Hisuian Sneasel usually struggles with.

Choice Item.description:
Hisuian Sneasel is an exceptional wielder of Choice items, with its high Speed, coveted access to Switcheroo, and hard-hitting STAB attacks in Close Combat and Gunk Shot. Throat Chop provides Hisuian Sneasel a powerful attack to break past Ghost-types like Mismagius, as well as threatening big damage against Psychic-types like Farigiraf and Mesprit, even blocking Psychic Noise; Swords Dance is an alternative that gives Hisuian Sneasel the capacity to function as a setup sweeper after it has shed its item. Switcheroo is a big reason Choice item sets function so well, as it can disrupt common switch-ins like Sandslash immensely. Choice Band grants Hisuian Sneasel the damage output needed to pick up 2HKOs on notable foes like Dipplin and Mesprit; Choice Scarf sets, on the other hand, trade power for Speed, turning Hisuian Sneasel into the fastest late-game cleaner and revenge killer, which is useful against usually speedier foes like Jolteon and Whimsicott. Tera Fighting boosts Close Combat tremendously, with Choice Band sets being capable of OHKOing Farigiraf and Lanturn, while also removing Hisuian Sneasel's weakness to Ground. Tera Dark grants Hisuian Sneasel a useful immunity to Psychic while making Throat Chop far more difficult to stomach for foes like Mesprit. Tera Dark also blocks Prankster from affecting Hisuian Sneasel, turning foes like Sableye and the more niche Volbeat into setup fodder.

A natural fit on bulky offense and balance teams, Hisuian Sneasel is a great choice as a Choice Band wallbreaker or Choice Scarf cleaner. Given Choice Band Hisuian Sneasel's propensity to blow holes in teams and force switches every time it hits the field, teammates that can help wear down walls like Dipplin, Regirock, and Spiritomb with entry hazards are much appreciated; Orthworm and Sandslash are great Spikes setters, and Mesprit is a notable Stealth Rock setter and pivot option. Other pivot options that can help Hisuian Sneasel get safe entry points in favorable matchups include Lanturn, which can invite in Snorlax. Choice Scarf Hisuian Sneasel appreciates other wallbreaker teammates that can enable it to pull off a late-game sweep, such as Choice Specs Magneton and Nasty Plot Spiritomb. Teammates that can help keep Charizard and Mesprit in check, like Snorlax, are valuable to provide defensive pivots for Hisuian Sneasel. Poison-type foes like Muk and Weezing can be difficult for Hisuian Sneasel to break through consistently, making Psychic-type partners like Farigiraf and Mesprit especially valuable. Similarly, Spiritomb can sponge Hisuian Sneasel's hits comfortably and use it as setup fodder, which makes Whimsicott valuable to threaten it back. Choice Band Hisuian Sneasel pairs well with setup sweepers like Swords Dance Virizion, as it can break holes in teams for Virizion to clean late-game or vice versa.

Regirock.comments:
Other Options

On paper, Sturdy gives a healthy Regirock a guaranteed turn to set up Stealth Rock, but between Regirock being so bulky and entry hazards being ubiquitous, it's unlikely that Regirock would be at risk of being OHKOed from full HP outside of uncommonly strong hits like Clawitzer's Water Pulse or Alolan Exeggutor's Leaf Storm. Regirock is totally dependent on the passive recovery from Leftovers to be a reliable wall, so even items like Heavy-Duty Boots and Rocky Helmet are suboptimal. Stone Edge is generally stronger than Rock Blast but has unreliable accuracy and poor PP, and it and Rock Slide cannot break past Substitute Pokemon. Curse can be used as a setup move over Iron Defense to power up Regirock's Rock Blast, but the extra Defense from Iron Defense is more useful to stonewall physical attackers, and Regirock's Body Press is more powerful and reliable than its STAB move anyway. Protect can enhance Regirock's recovery from Leftovers and allow Regirock to scout common Choice item attackers like Jolteon and Whimsicott, but it makes Regirock much more passive. Tera Ghost lets Regirock become immune to Fighting-type moves from major offensive threats like Virizion and Passimian while preserving Regirock's ability to check Snorlax and enabling it to block Rapid Spin from Sandslash and Toedscruel. Tera Grass helps Regirock manage its common Grass, Water, and Ground weaknesses, whereas Tera Water lets Regirock better handle Glastrier, and Tera Steel shares Tera Poison's poison immunity and Grass resistance while giving Regirock an easier time against Mesprit and Farigiraf. Regirock can run a Careful nature to patch up its relatively lower special bulk, but Regirock is often tasked with taking on physical attackers, and more Defense investment benefits its IronPress combination.

Checks and Counters

Ground-types: Sandaconda has great longevity, while Sandslash and Toedscruel can remove Regirock's entry hazards with Rapid Spin, but all three must be wary of Regirock boosting too much with Iron Defense.

Special Attackers: Regirock's lower special bulk leaves it prone to being overwhelmed by special attackers like Mesprit, Jolteon, and Rotom. Magneton can hit Regirock super effectively with its STAB Flash Cannon. However, most special attackers are physically frail, and Magneton takes a lot of damage from Regirock's Body Press. Many special attackers also cannot KO Regirock without significant chip or several boosts.

Fighting-types: Regirock's Fighting weakness can lead it to fall victim to Fighting-types like Passimian and Virizion. Hitmontop and Hitmonchan can both remove Regirock's Stealth Rock. However, Regirock can turn the tables on physically offensive Fighting-types with its IronPress combination and Terastallization.

Grass-types: Whimsicott, Alolan Exeggutor, and Sceptile can blow through Regirock with their strong super effective STAB moves, and Whimsicott is distinguished for avoiding a 2HKO from Regirock's Body Press after Stealth Rock. Alolan Exeggutor annihilates Regirock, while Dipplin can phaze Regirock with Dragon Tail and use Recover to wall it back.

Water-types: Poliwrath can use non-IronPress Regirock as setup fodder. Clawitzer can OHKO Regirock with Water Pulse but cannot switch into Regirock's Body Press more than once with Stealth Rock up. Veluza resists Body Press and can break through Regirock's Defense boosts with Aqua Cutter.

Knock Off, Trick, and Switcheroo: Regirock relies on its Leftovers for recovery, so Knock Off users like Sneasel and Mesprit are disruptive to Regirock. Mespirit and Hisuian Sneasel can use Trick and Switcheroo to disrupt Regirock by giving it their Choice items.

Residual damage: Burns and poison neutralize Regirock's already limited passive recovery. Burns from Will-O-Wisp users like Weezing and Rotom halve Regirock's damage output, while Toxic from Muk and Toedscruel puts Regirock on a timer. Entry hazards like Stealth Rock and Spikes cause Regirock to struggle to stay healthy.

Taunt and Encore: Encore users like Whimsicott and Mesprit can lock Regirock into a move to exploit it though neither enjoy taking Body Press. Froslass and Primeape can use Taunt to stop Regirock from setting up Stealth Rock or Iron Defense. Sableye can run Taunt or Encore and does not fear Regirock's Body Press.

Physical Wall.description:
Thanks to its titanic Defense, Regirock can stonewall popular physical attackers like Snorlax and Sneasel and use them as an opportunity to set up Stealth Rock. Rock Blast deals reliable damage to Typhlosion, Oricorio-F, and Charizard and breaks Substitute on users like Mismagius and Jolteon. Body Press crushes Snorlax, Ice-types like Glastrier and Sneasel, and Steel-types like Orthworm and Magneton. Iron Defense boosts Regirock's physical bulk and powers up Body Press, turning Regirock into a bulky setup sweeper capable of suffocating physical attackers like Snorlax and overwhelming walls like Sandaconda. Thunder Wave slows down setup sweepers like Hisuian Sneasel and fast Pokemon like Whimsicott but makes Regirock more passive. Clear Body helpfully denies stat debuffs from Intimidate, Shadow Ball, and Triple Arrows. 16 Defense EVs and an Impish nature is a useful jump point to balance Regirock's bulk. Tera Poison helps with Regirock's Grass and Fighting weaknesses and gives it an immunity to poison.

Regirock fits best on teams looking for a physically defensive backbone that can set up Stealth Rock. While Regirock has great physical bulk, its typing and comparatively lesser special bulk leave it more prone to strong special attacks. Specially defensive partners like Snorlax, Articuno, and Magneton complement Regirock's physical bulk and can intercept special attackers like Mismagius, Whimsicott, and Mesprit. Sandslash and Hitmontop can form entry hazard cores with Regirock and help keep it from taking entry hazard chip damage. Other Grass-type partners like Alolan Exeggutor, Dipplin, and Virizion are also appreciated by Regirock, as they can cover its Ground, Grass, and Water weaknesses by taking on Sandslash, opposing Dipplin, and Clawitzer, while Regirock can take on threatening Flying-types like Oricorio-F and Articuno.

Mismagius.overview: Mismagius's fantastic Speed and Special Attack stats, Ghost typing, and colorful coverage make it a powerful specially offensive threat. Nasty Plot sets can break specially bulky Pokemon like Lanturn, Regirock, and Articuno wide open, while Choice item sets lean into Mismagius's spammable STAB Shadow Ball. Terastallization greatly enables Mismagius offensively and defensively, especially with the synergies of Tera Fairy + Draining Kiss and Tera Electric + Levitate. However, Mismagius's bad physical bulk leaves it prone to fast physical attackers like Lycanroc, Sneasel, and Choice Scarf Passimian. Nasty Plot sets also struggle with Mismagius's frailty, reducing its opportunities to set up safely, especially when special walls like Snorlax can tank Mismagius's attacks and neutralize it.
Mismagius.comments:
Other Options

Mystical Fire nails Steel-types like Magneton and Orthworm alongside hitting Sneasel super effectively. However, Mismagius has better synergies available to it with Fairy-type coverage moves and Tera Fairy or Thunderbolt and Tera Electric. Will-O-Wisp can punish special walls like Regirock and Snorlax, but the latter tends to run Rest anyway, and some walls, like Lanturn, aren't hindered by an Attack drop. Choice item sets can run Tera Ghost to power up Mismagius's spammable STAB Shadow Ball, but Tera Fairy and Tera Electric are more valuable for offering Mismagius outs against Dark-type moves and paralysis, respectively.

Checks and Counters

Special Walls: Snorlax and Regirock can survive Mismagius's boosted attacks and hit it back hard, Articuno and Cryogonal can use Haze to remove Nasty Plot boosts, and Naclstack resists Shadow Ball and can use Salt Cure to wear Mismagius down. However, all special walls must be wary of Choice item Mismagius using Trick and Nasty Plot Mismagius using Taunt or Substitute.

Faster Attackers: Physical attackers like Lycanroc exploit Mismagius's much lower Defense. Sneasel resists Shadow Ball, safely threatens to OHKO Mismagius with Knock Off, and can play around Mismagius Terastallizing with Triple Axel. Jolteon commonly runs Shadow Ball for coverage, and it can use Volt Switch to chip down Mismagius into range of a KO. Choice Scarf users like Rotom-C and Mesprit can also finish off a weakened Mismagius.

Paralysis: Mismagius's frailty leaves it vulnerable to being revenge killed, so paralysis spreaders like Magneton and Lanturn can ruin it. Despite being weak to Ghost-type attacks, Mesprit and Hattrem are bulky enough to survive a Shadow Ball from non-Choice Specs Mismagius and paralyze it in desperation.

Nasty Plot.description:
Mismagius can use its Ground, Normal, and Fighting immunities to find setup opportunities with Nasty Plot, opening it up further as a special wallbreaker and cleaner. Draining Kiss provides Mismagius some extra recovery as it attacks, and Mismagius can use its special bulk to enable this strategy. Mismagius can alternatively run Dazzling Gleam for stronger coverage against Dark-types, OHKOing Sneasel with Life Orb or Tera Fairy's boost if it tries to switch in. Thunderbolt makes Mismagius more offensively potent against Flying-types like Articuno, and it's Mismagius's strongest coverage move against Normal-types like Snorlax, Grafaiai, and Farigiraf. Alternatively, Substitute provides Mismagius with protection from Naclstack's Salt Cure and revenge killers like Virizion. Taunt is a different utility option that shuts down special walls like Articuno and Crygonal in addition to denying Defog. Leftovers Mismagius variants can set up Substitute several times, and Draining Kiss sets can appreciate the additional longevity. In contrast, Life Orb makes Mismagius much more immediately threatening as a wallbreaker, giving it enough power to OHKO Charizard with Shadow Ball at +2. Tera Fairy powers up Mismagius's Fairy-type coverage moves, grants it a useful Dark resistance for intercepting Passimian's Knock Off, and creates an immunity to phazing by Dipplin's Dragon Tail. Mismagius can use Tera Electric as an alternative to shed all of its weaknesses, acquire a paralysis immunity to leverage against Lanturn and Magneton, and power up Thunderbolt to the point that it can OHKO Articuno at +2 with a Life Orb.

Mismagius fits offensive teams as a strong wallbreaker that opens up holes for fast cleaners like Virizion, Jolteon, and Choice Scarf Mesprit. Setup sweepers like Lycanroc and Hisuian Sneasel similarly appreciate Mismagius softening up teams early-game so that they can sweep. As a special sweeper, Oricorio-F especially benefits from Mismagius weakening special walls like Regirock. Sticky Web teams led by Vikavolt can rely on Mismagius as an offensive spinblocker, and Mismagius loves moving before faster foes like Lycanroc and Choice Scarf Passimian to KO them first. Spikes teams featuring Sandslash and Orthworm can also count on Mismagius to spinblock, and Mismagius thrives when grounded walls like Snorlax and Regirock are chipped down by entry hazards. Mismagius can struggle to break through grounded walls like Snorlax and Regirock without significant chip damage or a few rounds of damage from hazards, so teammates like Minior, Shaymin, and Poliwrath are helpful to take advantage of them or soften them up for Mismagius.

Choice Item.description:
Choice item Mismagius sets benefit from STAB Shadow Ball's great coverage against most of the metagame. Mismagius's coverage makes it troublesome for Ghost-immune and -resistant Pokemon to play around. Dazzling Gleam covers Dark-types like Persian-Alola and Sneasel, while Thunderbolt targets Dodrio and Articuno. Trick disrupts passive special walls by locking them into one move, which is especially devastating to item-reliant walls like Naclstack, Snorlax, Regirock, Articuno, and Cryogonal. With a Choice Scarf, Mismagius becomes one of the fastest threats in the boosted metagame, outpacing Choice Scarf users like Passimian and Shaymin as well as +1 Oricorio formes. Alternatively, Choice Specs Mismagius is an immediate wallbreaker that can threaten to OHKO staples like Charizard, Mesprit, and Hattrem. Tera Fairy boosts Mismagius's Dazzling Gleam and it provides Mismagius with a solid defensive typing to beat revenge killing attempts from Passimian's Knock Off. Mismagius gains a useful paralysis immunity with Tera Electric, allowing it to handle paralysis spreaders like Magneton and Mesprit, and with Choice Specs, Tera Electric Mismagius can 2HKO Articuno with Thunderbolt.

With a Choice Scarf, Mismagius can serve as a powerful Speed control option for offensive teams, helping them threaten fast attackers like Charizard and Shaymin. Mismagius's ability to debilitate special walls with a Choice item can improve offense teams' matchups against bulky teams, allowing special setup sweepers like Oricorio-F and Farigiraf to take off once special walls like Snorlax and Articuno are restricted. Mismagius can spinblock to maintain Vikavolt's Sticky Web, and Choice Specs Mismagius can outspeed faster foes like Choice Scarf Typhlosion with Sticky Web support. Spikes support from Sandslash and Orthworm helps wear down special walls like Snorlax, Regirock, and Naclstack for Mismagius, making it easier for Mismagius to overwhelm these foes, while Mismagius can spinblock and deal with Sandslash for the Ground-weak Regirock.

Spiritomb.comments:
Other Options

Physically offensive and mixed variants of Spiritomb can be used due to its access to Sucker Punch and Poltergeist, but there are far better options for physically offensive Dark-types like Mabosstiff and Sneasel, which boast superior Attack and Speed stats. Spiritomb can opt to use Pain Split or Will-O-Wisp instead of Psyshock on the offensive Trick Room set in order to improve its survivability and potentially ease setup at a heavy cost to its coverage, losing out on key targets like Virizion and Poliwrath.

Checks and Counters

Dark-types: Offensive Dark-type foes like Mabosstiff and Sneasel resist Spiritomb's STAB Dark Pulse and retaliate with excellent damage themselves, though they must be wary of physically defensive variants that can debilitate them with Will-O-Wisp.

Fairy-types: As the tier's best Fairy-type Pokemon, Whimsicott can take on Spiritomb's boosted attacks and threaten heavy damage with Moonblast. Tera Fairy walls like Mesprit, Snorlax, and Dipplin can resist Spiritomb's STAB Dark Pulse to stop its sweep or further their own setup.

Wallbreakers: Spiritomb's lackluster natural bulk can be easily preyed upon by wallbreakers like Mabosstiff, Jolteon, and Vikavolt regardless of what set it's running, though they must be careful when switching in.

Encore: While it is immune to Prankster Encore from the likes of Whimsicott and Sableye, Spiritomb must be wary of a potential Encore from other foes like Mesprit, Beartic, and non-Prankster variants of the previously mentioned Whimsicott.

Special Walls: Specially defensive walls like Cryogonal and Articuno can wipe away Spiritomb's Nasty Plot boosts with Haze; in addition, Articuno can also phaze Spiritomb with Roar.

Offensive Trick Room.description:
Spiritomb utilizes its defensive profile to switch into foes like Passimian and Hisuian Sneasel, setting up and devastating teams in a tier almost completely lacking Fairy-type Pokemon. Dark Pulse serves as an amazing neutral STAB attack for a vast majority of the tier, threatening OHKOs on metagame staples like Jolteon and Mesprit after a Nasty Plot boost; it is the preferred STAB over Shadow Ball to avoid letting Normal-type Pokemon like Snorlax and Farigiraf switch in for free. Psyshock compliments Dark Pulse excellently with its ability to hit Fighting-types like Poliwrath and Virizion while targeting opposing special walls like Snorlax and Lanturn on their comparatively worse Defense. Alternatively, Tera Blast Steel targets Dark-types like Sableye and Mabosstiff alongside Fairy-types like Whimsicott and Tera Fairy Mesprit. Tera Dark further amplifies the power of Spiritomb's Dark Pulse to OHKO as many foes as possible once boosted, securing guaranteed OHKOs on foes like Rotom-C and Charizard, while Tera Steel allows for the usage of Tera Blast as well as shoring up Spiritomb's Fairy weakness.

Spiritomb works well alongside wallbreakers like Virizion, Glastrier, and Hisuian Sneasel, which can wallbreak for each other and enable Spiritomb's sweep. Spiritomb struggles with strong physical attacks from the likes of Mabosstiff and Sneasel, so it appreciates physical walls like Regirock and Weezing that can reliably switch into them. Special attackers like Jolteon, Vikavolt, and Mesprit pair well with Spiritomb to break down walls for each other. Teammates with pivoting moves like Rotom-C, Lanturn, Jolteon, and Passimian can help bring Spiritomb in safely to help ease its setup. Entry hazard support from the likes of Regirock, Sandslash, and Mesprit is also greatly appreciated to help whittle foes into range for Spiritomb to sweep. Pokemon that can threaten Whimsicott like Muk and Magneton are appreciated to help cover for Spiritomb's lone weakness to Fairy.

Abomasnow.overview: With the combination of Aurora Veil, Snow Warning, and a strong offensive profile, Abomasnow is ZU's sole viable snow setter and a threatening offensive tank. The Defense boost from snow even helps Abomasnow tank attacks like Glastrier's Close Combat and Lycanroc's Stone Edge. Abomasnow's snow pairs well with Beartic, enabling the latter's Slush Rush for formidable late-game sweeps. Aurora Veil is also invaluable support for teammates like Jolteon and Charizard, allowing them to more easily wreak havoc against the opposition. Abomasnow itself can dish out powerful STAB attacks courtesy of its threatening offensive stats and coverage. Abomasnow, however, is hindered by its low Speed and awful defensive typing, leaving it vulnerable to special attackers like Charizard and Magneton without the help of Terastallization. Without Heavy-Duty Boots, Abomasnow is very vulnerable to getting worn down by entry hazards. Abomasnow faces competition from other offensive Grass-types like Shaymin and Virizion for their faster Speed and better defensive profiles, though Abomasnow stands out for its unique ability and offensive typing.
Abomasnow.comments:
Other Options

Focus Blast nails Orthworm and deals more damage to special walls and tanks like Snorlax and Glastrier, though its shaky accuracy makes it an inconsistent option. On more offensive teams, Eject Pack can make Abomasnow a one-time pivot with Leaf Storm, while Icy Rock can be run to give Beartic more turns of snow for sweeping. However, not running Heavy-Duty Boots exacerbates Abomasnow's vulnerability to residual damage. Physical sets can surprise special walls like Snorlax and Cryogonal, though they struggle by lacking a strong physical Ice-type STAB move and being less effective overall. Leech Seed can be used to discourage special walls like Snorlax and Muk from staying in on Abomasnow, though it can't afford dropping Aurora Veil or coverage.

Checks and Counters

Fire-types: Even when Abomasnow has the Defense boost under snow, Fire-types like Charizard, Oricorio, and Typhlosion can melt it with their powerful STAB moves and switch into its Grass-type attacks.

Special Walls: Despite Abomasnow's powerful STAB moves, special tanks like Snorlax, Articuno, and Cryogonal can stomach its attacks and reliably recover the damage off before chipping it away with their own STAB attacks; Snorlax is particularly dangerous with its Heat Crash.

Steel-types: Orthworm stands out as one of Abomasnow's most difficult matchups, resisting both of its STAB moves, being immune to Earth Power, and being able to retaliate by setting up entry hazards or Iron Defense. Other Steel-types like Magneton and Perrserker are similarly threatening but hate Earth Power.

Faster Pokemon: Abomasnow's awful defensive typing and merely fine bulk leave it vulnerable to numerous attackers faster than it. Revenge killers and wallbreakers like Passimian, Virizion, and Lycanroc are just a few examples that can pick it off with some chip damage, even if they dislike switching into it.

Aurora Veil.description:
Abomasnow is a chilling offensive tank courtesy of its offensive typing and the combination of Snow Warning and Blizzard. Giga Drain provides consistent recovery for Abomasnow and hits Water-types like Lanturn and Poliwrath, though Leaf Storm can be used for immediate burst damage at the cost of lowering its offensive stats and forgoing healing. Earth Power is Abomasnow's strongest option against Steel-types like Magneton as well as Typhlosion. Heavy-Duty Boots covers Abomasnow's Stealth Rock vulnerability so it can effectively tank attacks and set up Aurora Veil. While other Pokemon are preferred for Terastallization, Tera Water can help in a pinch to shield Abomasnow from Fire-types like Charizard and Typhlosion.

Abomasnow tends to fit on offensive and balanced builds thanks to its offensive typing and the support provided by Aurora Veil. Offensive pivots like Mesprit and Jolteon appreciate it to better take damage from potential Choice Scarf users like opposing Mesprit and Hisuian Sneasel; Jolteon also benefits from having a more threatening coverage move under snow with Ice-type Weather Ball. Beartic particularly stands out as a partner, benefiting from the Defense boost under snow and having its sweeping capabilities enabled with Slush Rush. Other setup sweepers like Minor, Oricorio, and Nasty Plot Mesprit benefit from the extra bulk under Aurora Veil giving them more opportunities to break or sweep. Abomasnow's plethora of weaknesses leaves it vulnerable to U-turn users and Fire-types; defensive backbones like Lanturn, Mesprit, and Snorlax can provide support with their bulk and utility moves. Additionally, Lanturn can provide paralysis support with Thunder Wave, and the latter two can rack up residual damage with entry hazards. Abomasnow can, in return, switch into weaker walls like Dipplin, Lanturn, and Sandslash to threaten them away with powerful STAB moves. Hazard deterrents like Hattrem and Sandslash stand out as notable teammates, with the former providing Magic Bounce, paralysis, and Healing Wish support, while the latter can remove hazards and provide Knock Off utility.

Rotom-Mow.overview: Rotom-C is one of the most potent offensive threats in ZU thanks to its great offensive coverage and Special Attack. Electric-immune Pokemon like Lanturn and Sandslash are weak to Leaf Storm, which makes Rotom-C a punishing pivot and difficult to stop. Choice Scarf sets outspeed the entire unboosted metagame, while bulky sets provide excellent team support with their utility moves. Levitate is fantastic as defensive utility, giving Rotom-C opportunities to switch in and threaten Ground-types and keeping it from being worn down by Spikes. Rotom-C isn't lacking utility, either, with moves like Trick, Will-O-Wisp, Thunder Wave, and Pain Split at its disposal. Terastallization is great for pushing Rotom-C's power to greater heights, giving it a great defensive typing with Levitate for setup opportunities and providing coverage to Nasty Plot sets in conjunction with Tera Blast. However, Rotom-C struggles to do much to Grass-types like Virizion, Shaymin, and Dipplin.
Rotom-Mow.comments:
Other Options

Nasty Plot sets can use Tera Blast as a fourth move in conjunction with Tera types, such as Poison, that improve their coverage. Choice Specs sets are prediction-reliant and aren't especially fast, but they can surprise and wear down walls like Snorlax and Muk.

Checks and Counters

Grass-types: Bulky Grass-types like Lurantis, Dipplin, and Arboliva resist Rotom-C's STAB moves and can remain healthy against it. Physical attackers like Dipplin and Virizion must be wary of Will-O-Wisp, while defensive Grass-types like Lurantis and Arboliva become prone when given a Choice Scarf by Trick. However, Dipplin is a menace to Rotom-C because of its immunity to Trick and potential to use Rotom-C as setup fodder.

Snorlax: Snorlax can tank boosted attacks from Rotom-C and hit it back hard, but it is punished by Trick. Non-Rest variants of Snorlax are not fans of Pain Split or Will-O-Wisp.

Poison-types: Hisuian Sneasel threatens Rotom-C with its Poison-type STAB moves, but it should watch out for Will-O-Wisp. Muk has the bulk to withstand boosted attacks from Rotom-C and hit it back hard. Weezing is a bit weaker on the special side, but can hit hard with Sludge Bomb.

Bulky Electric-types: Vikavolt resists Rotom-C's STAB moves and threatens it back hard with Bug Buzz, while Magneton can similarly beat Rotom-C one-on-one. If Lanturn Terastallizes into a Dragon-type, then it becomes a very capable check to Rotom-C, and Volt Absorb variants can stop Rotom-C from pivoting.

Ice-types: Sneasel and Cryogonal both outspeed Rotom-C and hit it hard with their Ice-type moves; Sneasel has Ice Shard to deal with Choice Scarf variants, and Cryogonal has good special bulk. Glastrier is bulky, but it is vulnerable to Will-O-Wisp.

Choice Scarf.description:
Choice Scarf Rotom-C outspeeds the entire unboosted metagame and makes a great revenge killer against offensive threats like Charizard and Choice Scarf Passimian. Rotom-C excels as a pivot because of Electric-immune Pokemon like Sandslash and Volt Absorb Lanturn taking major damage from Leaf Storm, and few of these Pokemon run coverage to hit Rotom-C back hard. Volt Switch helps Rotom-C keep up momentum as it finishes off foes, and it lets it put Grass-type switch-ins like Dipplin on the backfoot. Trick punishes walls to Rotom-C like Arboliva and Snorlax by restricting them with a Choice lock, but it can also help against offensive foes, such as Virizion and Shaymin, that prefer to switch their moves and don't benefit especially from a Choice Scarf. Tera Electric makes Rotom-C's Thunderbolt and Volt Switch even more powerful, and shedding Rotom-C's Grass typing improves its matchups against Oricorio-F and Sneasel.

Rotom-C's ability to keep up the tempo for its team makes it a great pick for offense teams. Other pivots can make great VoltTurn cores with Rotom-C. Charizard threatens Grass-types like Shaymin, and it appreciates Rotom-C pressuring bulky Rock- and Ground-types like Regirock and Sandslash. Rotom-C becomes more vulnerable once it's used Leaf Storm, and Regirock can switch into foes like Charizard and Sneasel that would try to take advantage of it. As a pivot, Rotom-C can support wallbreakers like Sneasel, Charizard, Typhlosion, and Glastrier, all of which can prey on the Grass-types that Rotom-C invites in. If Rotom-C doesn't use Volt Switch as specially defensive walls like Snorlax and Cryogonal switch in, then physical tanks and bulky wallbreakers like Regirock and Glastrier can switch in and deal with these foes. Since Rotom-C is still slower than Choice Scarf users like Typhlosion, Mismagius, and Hisuian Sneasel, bulky partners like Snorlax and Sandaconda can pivot into these foes for Rotom-C.

Nasty Plot.description:
Thanks to Rotom-C's Electric- and Grass-type STAB moves, Nasty Plot sets can shred bulky cores that rely on walls like Lanturn, Regirock, and Orthworm. Discharge is an alternative to Thunderbolt that punishes walls like Cryogonal and Dipplin with paralysis so that Rotom-C or a teammate can more easily overwhelm them. Volt Switch lets Rotom-C keep up momentum against its switch-ins if it's not in a position to sweep, giving it more utility in the early- and mid-game. Pain Split keeps Rotom-C healthy against bulky foes like Snorlax and Muk, and the HP-lowering effect can put them into positions to be overwhelmed by Rotom-C. Will-O-Wisp punishes Grass-types and special walls looking to intercept Rotom-C like Muk and Snorlax. A bulkier EV spread affords Rotom-C more opportunities to set up Nasty Plot, but a more offensive one lets Rotom-C break through weakened walls like Snorlax more easily and with fewer boosts. If Rotom-C opts to run Volt Switch, then Heavy-Duty Boots will generally add more to its longevity than Leftovers. Tera Ghost throws off Fighting-type revenge killers like Passimian and Hisuian Sneasel, and the Fighting immunity it grants can save Rotom-C against Tera Dragon Regirock's Iron Defense-boosted Body Press. The Fire resistance provided by Tera Dragon helps Rotom-C against Fire-type revenge killers like Charizard and Typhlosion, and it preserves Rotom-C's natural Electric, Grass, and Water resistances. Tera Steel gives Rotom-C a good defensive typing that offers it more setup opportunities against special walls like Muk and the ability to flip its matchups for a critical turn against revenge killers like Sneasel and Choice Scarf Mesprit.

Rotom-C's ability to pressure defensive Pokemon is an asset for offense, bulky offense, and balance teams. Spikes from entry hazard setters like Sandslash and Orthworm helps wear down checks to Rotom-C like Dipplin, Muk, and Snorlax. Stealth Rock from setters like Mesprit, Regirock, and Sandslash can also passively get chip damage on these checks to Rotom-C, and in turn, Rotom-C threatens entry hazard removers like Sandslash. Special sweepers like Oricorio-F and Farigiraf can sweep late-game once Rotom-C has softened up special walls like Snorlax for them. Physical wallbreakers like Glastrier and Hisuian Sneasel apply pressure to special walls Rotom-C struggles against, while Rotom-C threatens Regirock and Poliwrath. Fire-types like Charizard, Oricorio-F, and Typhlosion can melt the Grass-types that are obstacles to Rotom-C like Whimsicott and Shaymin, while Rotom-C can pressure Regirock and Lanturn for these Fire-type teammates. Offensive Poison-types like and Hisuian Sneasel can be handled by Ground-type teammates like Sandslash and Sandaconda. Additionally, these Poison-types can actually make great partners for Rotom-C itself, as they can pressure Grass-types for it, and they also appreciate Rotom-C's good matchups against Ground-types. Glastrier, Regirock, and Poliwrath can handily handle fast Ice-types like Sneasel and Froslass for Rotom-C.

Bulky Pivot.description:
Rotom-C's decent bulk and STAB combination make it a reliable and potent bulky pivot, punishing Electric-immune Pokemon like Sandslash and Lanturn with Leaf Storm. Pain Split capitalizes on Rotom-C's low natural HP and provides it with recovery beyond Leftovers. High-HP Pokemon like Snorlax and Muk looking to switch into Rotom-C are prime targets for Pain Split and otherwise comfortably stomach Rotom-C's attacks. Will-O-Wisp neuters physical attackers like the aforementioned high-HP Pokemon as well as Passimian and Virizion. Alternatively, Thunder Wave can slow down fast threats like Mismagius and Whimsicott. Leftovers is Rotom-C's only form of recovery beyond Pain Split, while Heavy-Duty Boots keeps it healthier in the face of entry hazards as it pivots. Tera Ghost provides Rotom-C extra defensive presence against Hisuian Sneasel and Virizion to hinder them with status. The resistances provided by Tera Dragon help Rotom-C deal with Fire-type threats like Charizard and Oricorio-F while preserving its Water, Electric, and Grass resistances, ensuring it maintains its positive matchups against Lanturn and opposing Rotom-C. Tera Steel disrupts Psychic-types like Mesprit and Farigiraf, and its synergy with Levitate works well against Ground-types like Sandslash and Sandaconda.

Rotom-C's capacity to punish Electric-immune Pokemon with Leaf Storm makes it a good fit for VoltTurn teams. Offensive pivots like Passimian and Perrserker form good pivot cores with Rotom-C. In particular, Passimian nails bulky Normal-types as well as Cryogonal, and Perrserker pressures Grass-types like Shaymin as well as Arboliva. Clawitzer can tank a Fire-type attack and break through special walls like Snorlax as well as Arboliva, and it benefits from Rotom-C drawing in and pivoting out on these targets for it. Regirock, Snorlax, and Lanturn can answer Fire-types like Charizard and Oricorio-F for Rotom-C. While Rotom-C does have an immunity to Spikes, it still appreciates Stealth Rock being off the field as it pivots if it's not holding Heavy-Duty Boots; Sandslash, Hitmontop, and Hattrem can all keep the field clear for Rotom-C. Rotom-C's ability to deal with Lanturn and Regirock is greatly appreciated by Fire-types like Charizard, Typhlosion, and Oricorio-F. Other powerful offensive threats, such as Mismagius, benefit from the free switches Rotom-C can provide with Volt Switch. Notably, Glastrier, Sneasel, and Hisuian Sneasel can deal with the Grass-types that Rotom-C invites in. Setup sweepers with middling Speed like Mesprit and Malamar can set up more easily thanks to the positioning Rotom-C can provide, and the latter presures Grass-types. Specially defensive walls like Snorlax and Lanturn can switch into Vikavolt for Rotom-C, while Ground-types like Sandslash and Sandaconda can deal with faster Poison-types like Hisuian Sneasel for Rotom-C.

Mesprit.overview: Mesprit is a highly flexible Pokemon that is capable of fulfulling a multitude of roles within the ZU metagame. Its balanced stats and useful movepool allow Mesprit to work well in offensive and defensive utility roles, while its Nasty Plot set is a threatening sweeper that is extremely challenging for bulky builds to deal with. Mesprit is also a good check to Fighting-types such as Virizion and Passimian, and Levitate lets it deal with many Ground-types, such as Sandslash and Sandaconda. Unfortunately, Mesprit's balanced stats means that it isn't truly exceptional at any role that it tries to play, as its offensive stats aren't fantastic, and bulky sets are prone to getting chipped down over time. Its Psychic typing also leaves it vulnerable to common Dark-types, such as Sneasel, Spiritomb, and Persian-Alola, while also leaving it weak to the ubiquitous U-turn. Finally, Mesprit's coverage is quite limited, as it lacks a way to hit Steel-types hard and doesn't hit much of the metagame for super effective damage. This can lead to it sometimes struggling to break through bulky threats such as Articuno and Snorlax.
Mesprit.comments:
Other Options

A Choice Specs set utilizing Psychic, Dazzling Gleam, Psyshock or Shadow Ball, and either Trick or U-turn is feasible. However, Mesprit isn't powerful enough to consistently break down defensive cores without perfect prediction, it can't hit Steel-types for significant damage, and its mediocre Speed tier means it isn't especially good against offensive teams either. The Nasty Plot set can consider Psychic Noise or Stored Power as its Psychic-type STAB move. The former prevents recovery from the likes of Articuno, Pallosand, and Snorlax, while the latter will become extremely powerful if Mesprit accrues multiple Nasty Plot boosts. However, Psyshock's ability to pressure common special walls like Lanturn, Snorlax, and Articuno makes it the most consistent option. The defensive pivot set can consider Colbur Berry as an alternative item to take Knock Off from the likes of Passimian and Sneasel, as well as Dark-type attacks from Spiritomb. However, the loss of Leftovers recovery means that only offensive teams looking to play fast should consider this, and it loses value if Mesprit is forced to Terastallize. The defensive pivot could also use other Tera types, such as Tera Fairy to give a Dark resistance that is useful when facing down Sneasel, Spiritomb, and Passimian and Tera Water to grant useful resistances for Typhlosion and Clawitzer. Tera Water, however, leaves Mesprit open to common Grass- and Electric-type attacks from Shaymin, Jolteon, and Virizion. Options like Thunder Wave to deter setup or and Pain Split to give Mesprit some form of recovery may seem appealing for the defensive set, but Mesprit tends to perform its role more consistently with the given moves.

Checks and Counters

Dark-types and Dark-type Coverage: Dark-types such as Sneasel, Spiritomb, and Persian-Alola threaten Mesprit with their STAB moves and either force it to switch out or Terastallize. Mesprit is capable of pivoting out or hitting them with Fairy-type coverage as they switch in, however. Pokemon that Mesprit would otherwise check, such as Passimian, Hisuian Sneasel, and Sandslash often run Dark-type coverage, limiting its ability to comfortably deal with them. Sableye and Spiritomb don't fear Mesprit's STAB moves, and Sableye can threaten to lock Mesprit into an ineffective move with Prankster Encore, though neither of them appreciate Fairy-type coverage, Knock Off, or Trick.

Ghost-types: Ghost-type attackers such as Mismagius, offensive Froslass, and Rotom threaten Mesprit with their STAB moves, but they can't comfortably switch in to most sets due to the threat of Knock Off, Trick, or a STAB move.

Steel-types: Steel-types such as Orthworm, Magneton, and Perrserker resist Mesprit's common coverage options, and they can use it as an opportunity to fire off a strong attack or, in Orthworm's case, set up Stealth Rock, Spikes, Coil, or Iron Defense. However, they must be wary of Trick or Knock Off. Additionally, certain Pokemon Mesprit usually checks, such as Weezing and Articuno, often run Tera Steel and can therefore turn the tables on Mesprit.

Strong Wallbreakers: Mesprit's rather modest bulk means it can't comfortably answer many of the tier's strongest offensive threats. Typhlosion and Jolteon outrun non-Choice Scarf Mesprit and threaten to do serious damage, even to the defensive set. Even slow wallbreakers such as Alolan Exeguttor and Clawitzer are still faster than the defensive pivot set and threaten it with extreme damage.

Choice Scarf.description:
Choice Scarf Mesprit is a great revenge killer to handle fast Pokemon like Jolteon and Hisuian Sneasel. Dazzling Gleam is Mesprit's best complementary coverage move for Psychic, covering Dark-types like Sneasel and Sableye. U-turn lets Mesprit keep up offensive momentum against switch-ins like Orthworm, Farigiraf, and Snorlax. Healing Wish lets Mesprit give teammates like Virizion, Snorlax, and Glastrier a second chance to set up and sweep. Mesprit can alternatively use Trick to make a defensive Pokemon like Snorlax or Orthworm less threatening. Tera Fairy Mesprit is a more effective offensive and defensive answer to Sneasel and Passimian given their Dark-type coverage moves, and Tera Fairy lets Mesprit not play guessing games with Psychic and Dazzling Gleam against Tera Dark Passimian. Tera Steel has good synergy with Levitate and gives Mesprit several new resistances to more easily answer Whimsicott, Sandslash, and Farigiraf.

Offensive pivots like Jolteon and Magneton make great cores with Mesprit and appreciate Mesprit's Levitate to more easily play around Ground-types. Fighting-types like Virizion, Passimian, and Hitmontop are great offensive checks to Snorlax and Steel-types like Orthworm and Perrserker, all of which give Mesprit trouble, and they appreciate Mesprit offensively checking Poison-types like Weezing and Hisuian Sneasel. Mesprit benefits from Ground-type teammates like Sandslash and Sandaconda patching up its poor matchup against Sneasel-Hisui, while it can check foes like Virizion for them. Setup sweepers like Oricorio-F, Regirock, and Virizion benefit from Mesprit providing them second chances to sweep with Healing Wish or making foes more exploitable with Trick. Physical wallbreakers like Glastrier and Hisuian Sneasel all benefit from Healing Wish giving them an additional chance for breaking, as they can break special walls that Mesprit cannot.

Nasty Plot Sweeper.description:
Nasty Plot Mesprit is a fearsome mid- or late-game sweeper thanks to the combination of Levitate and a somewhat high base 105 Special Attack stat. Its biggest perk is the ability to set up in front of most bulkier Pokmon. Mesprit can choose between Encore and Substitute as its setup tool; Substitute can be very good versus bulkier teams, as Mesprit can tank a hit from most of the passive mons such as Regirock and Lanturn if not being hit super effectively, obtaining a free turn to either set up Nasty Plot or fire off an attack. Encore helps to circumvent Mesprit's passivity and can take advantage of checks that need to set up or use status moves like Haze to wall Mesprit, like Articuno for the Haze case, and Regirock for the setup. Psyshock is great to deal with specially defensive Pokmon such as Snorlax. Draining Kiss allows Mesprit to outlast Dark-type checks such as Spiritomb and Sneasel while healing in the process, Thunderbolt allows it to hit and Flying- and Water-types such as Charizard and Clawitzer hard. Tera Fairy lets Mesprit set up in front of the aforementioned Dark-types, grants immunity to Dragon Tail from Dipplin and Appletun, and increases the power of Draining Kiss, letting Mesprit restore more HP on the aforementioned threats and making it even harder to take down. Tera Steel improves Mesprit's defensive capabilities, making it take neutral damage from Dark- and Ghost-type attacks and giving it a Bug resistance, while only being weak to Fighting- and Fire-type moves due to Levitate. Tera Electric boosts the power of Thunderbolt and removes all of Mesprit's weaknesses.

Nasty Plot Sweeper Mesprit works well with specific entry hazard setters and Fighting-types. Hazard setters like Orthworm and Naclstack both cover each other's weaknesses and let Mesprit get rolls it wouldn't otherwise, such as KOing Honchkrow with Tera Fairy Draining Kiss after Stealth Rock chip damage. Fighting-types such as Virizion and Passimian deserve a highlight, as when paired with Mesprit, they provide good coverage for it, pressuring Dark- and Steel-types with their STAB moves and Ghost-types with Knock Off. Both of them offer additional utility, with Virizion being bulky enough to enter in and provide wallbreaking prowess and Passimian having access to U-turn to let Mesprit in safely and Knock Off to offer utility. Secondary wallbreakers that don't rely on Setup to make progress such as Clawitzer and Magneton will also appreciate being by Mesprit's side. Some cleaners also enjoy Mesprit's ability to make progress so they can clean late-game, such as Dodrio and Hisuian Sneasel.

Specially Defensive Pivot.description:
Mesprit's decent defensive profile and access to useful utility moves like Stealth Rock and Healing Wish allow it to act as a good defensive pivot. Its bulk and typing allows it to check foes such as Jolteon, Charizard, and Passimian locked into Close Combat. Psychic Noise is a useful STAB move that allows Mesprit to force out Hitmonchan and Hitmontop, which are among the few viable hazard removers of the tier. Its decent Base Power and ability to prevent healing allow Mesprit to annoy other defensive Pokemon like Dipplin and Sandaconda. U-turn allows Mesprit to pivot out of poor matchups such as Glastrier and Spiritomb while keeping up momentum for its team. Knock Off allows Mesprit to punish foes that would feel comfortable coming in otherwise, such as Orthworm, Articuno, and Snorlax. Healing Wish is another option for offensive teams that allows Mesprit to fully heal an offensive teammate and give it another go at breaking down the opponent's team. It is capable of running both Knock Off and Healing Wish if your team already has another Stealth Rock user. Maximum Special Defense investment is preferred in order to better take hits from the likes of Charizard, Magneton, and Pyroar. A Sassy nature is preferred to give Mesprit a slow U-turn and maximize the damage that its physical attacks do. Steel is the preferred Tera type, as it turns each of Mesprit's weaknesses into a neutrality or a resistance and gives it a superb general defensive typing. It notably lets Mesprit handle opposing Mesprit and Whimsicott with more confidence. Tera Steel also has good synergy with Levitate and allows Mesprit to comfortably handle foes such as Sandslash and Sandaconda. Leftovers grants Mesprit passive recovery and helps it stay as healthy as possible throughout the match.

Mesprit is one of the few bulky Stealth Rock setters in the tier that also has access to a pivoting move, which makes it highly useful for both balance and offense. Mesprit lacks reliable recovery, so teams utilizing it shouldn't expect it to be a stalwart wall. Rather, its good support movepool and defensive traits allow it to act as a stopgap that can take a few hits while also supporting its offensively oriented teammates via pivoting and utility moves such as Knock Off and Healing Wish. Mesprit's physical bulk is somewhat lacking, so physically defensive teammates such as Weezing and Sandaconda, make for good partners. These two help out against Fighting-types such as Passimian and Hisuian Sneasel, which Mesprit struggles to check in the long term. Dipplin serves as a good physically defensive partner and in particular a Knock Off absorber, which is highly useful for Mesprit because it fears Knock Off greatly. Mesprit is also vulnerable to Dark-types such as Spiritomb and Sneasel. Teammates such as Hisuian Sneasel and Virizion can help with the latter, while Articuno and Whimsicott can help with the former. Teammates such as Passimian, Virizion, and Charizard can help check Steel-types such as Magneton and Orthworm, which Mesprit struggles to deal with on its own. Strong wallbreakers, such as Typhlosion, Glastrier, and Alolan Exeggutor, appreciate Mesprit's slow U-turn getting them in safely, and they benefit from Mesprit's ability to use Knock Off to remove various items from defensive Pokemon such as Regirock, Orthworm, and Articuno. Mesprit also pairs well with other VoltTurn users; Passimian and Whimsicott also benefit from Mesprit bringing them in safely and can form a pivoting core that can slowly wear down the opponent's team. Pokemon such as Typhlosion, Charizard, and Glastrier appreciate Healing Wish support should Mesprit choose to run it, as they are all vulnerable to being worn down over the course of a match, and many teams are not prepared to deal with them a second time.

Shaymin.overview: Shaymin is blessed with well-rounded bulk, solid Special Attack, and great Speed, enabling it to tap into its colorful coverage to act as a potent specially offensive threat. Seed Flare is a potent offensive STAB move, and it can make Shaymin into a deadly wallbreaker if it gets lucky with Special Defense drops against would-be checks like Snorlax and Muk. A gifted utility movepool makes Shaymin surprisingly flexible when building with it and using it, and Shaymin's customizability makes it even more threatening because of how unpredictable it is. Natural Cure even makes Shaymin a rare, viable status absorber, giving it an edge in taking advantage of status spreaders like Lanturn, Rotom-C, and Hattrem. However, Shaymin has a lot of competition from other Grass-types like Rotom-C, Whimsicott, Virizion, and Dipplin for spots on teams, and its own Grass typing is a liability against major threats like Charizard, Oricorio-F.
Shaymin.comments:
Other Options

Shaymin's well-rounded stats and flexibility suit it as a good user of Terastallization, so it can tap into a variety of alternative Tera types. Tera Ghost offers Shaymin a good defensive typing against Hisuian Sneasel and other Poison-types, helps Shaymin spinblock against Sandslash, and annoys Snorlax and Terastallized IronPress Regirock. Tera Rock + Tera Blast can catch Charizard and Articuno, but dedicating a moveslot to this makes Shaymin more dependent on Terastallization at the cost of its teammates losing the ability to rely on such a valuable resource.

Checks and Counters

Flying-types: Charizard and Oricorio-F take 4x resisted damage from Shaymin's Seed Flare, and Articuno can waste Seed Flare PP with Pressure. Both Oricorio-F and Articuno have reliable recovery to wall Shaymin.

Special Walls: Without Special Defense drops, Snorlax and Orthworm can be a pain for Shaymin to take down on its own. Cryogonal can use Haze to remove any stat drops.

Poison-types: Muk has the best special bulk out of any Poison-type and can tank Earth Power, but even it must be wary of Special Defense drops. Hisuian Sneasel naturally outspeeds Shaymin, barring Choice Scarf. Weezing has Levitate for Earth Power, but Shaymin can overwhelm it even more easily than Muk by dropping its Special Defense with Seed Flare.

Ice-types: Sneasel naturally outspeeds non-Choice Scarf Shaymin and can pick off Choice Scarf variants with Ice Shard. Glastrier is bulky enough to tank an attack from Shaymin and usually KO it in return. Beartic can outspeed non-Choice Scarf Shaymin under snow.

Vikavolt: Even when it's uninvested, Vikavolt's STAB Bug Buzz OHKOes Shaymin, and Vikavolt is bulky enough to tank Shaymin's attacks provided it doesn't have its Special Defense dropped.

Offensive.description:
Seed Flare's high Base Power and solid chance to drop a foe's Special Defense make Shaymin a potent offensive threat that can break down its own checks with its coverage and some good luck. Earth Power targets Poison-types like Hisuian Sneasel and Muk as well as other Grass-resistant foes like Typhlosion and Magneton. Air Slash covers opposing Grass-types like Arboliva and Lurantis. Dazzling Gleam is an alternative coverage move that synergizes with Tera Fairy and still acts as a good coverage move against Virizion, Dipplin, and Alolan Exeggutor. Shaymin can use its well-rounded bulk and Synthesis to outlast and overwhelm passive foes like Regirock and Orthworm as well as Rotom-C. Healing Wish leans more into Shaymin's role as an offensive support for its team, which can make up for Shaymin's limited Grass-type coverage by giving a teammate a second wind or free switch. Rest is an alternative recovery option that takes advantage of Natural Cure curing Shaymin's sleep status once it switches out. The protection against entry hazards that Heavy-Duty Boots provides enables Shaymin to worry less about its longevity, so Heavy-Duty Boots sets can more aggressively pivot onto the field to absorb status or passive attackers with hazards up. Additionally, Heavy-Duty Boots Shaymin has a better matchup against Sticky Web teams thanks to Shaymin's good natural Speed. Choice Scarf Shaymin sets take advantage of Seed Flare's spammability and Shaymin's great Speed tier for a Choice Scarf user, and the Speed boost from Choice Scarf helps Shaymin more consistently use Healing Wish. Life Orb variants crank Shaymin's power up higher to break down special walls like Snorlax, and they share the moveset flexibility of Heavy-Duty Boots variants that can flex Shaymin's colorful coverage to beat down Muk. Shaymin can also use Synthesis or Rest to mitigate the recoil damage from running Life Orb. Shaymin is a flexible user of Terastallization thanks to not relying on it to function yet still having well-rounded stats and diverse coverage for good offensive and defensive Terastallization. Tera Ground powers up Earth Power and gives Shaymin a useful Poison resistance to improve its matchups against Poison-types like Weezing and Muk. Alternatively, Tera Fairy grants Shaymin a good defensive typing that's disruptive against Dragon- and Fighting-types like Dipplin and Passimian.

Shaymin's customizability earns it spots on multiple team archetypes. Hyper offense teams appreciate Healing Wish and can rely on Shaymin's decent bulk and wallbreaking abilities. Shaymin has the natural bulk for bulky offense teams and the power to keep up as a wallbreaker, and its ability to absorb status can let it play more aggressively. Special sweepers like Oricorio-F, Farigiraf, and Jolteon appreciate Shaymin softening up walls like Snorlax, Orthworm, and Muk so that they can more efficiently sweep. Other special wallbreakers like Charizard, Typhlosion, and Magneton can pair with Shaymin to overwhelm their shared checks in the aforementioned walls, and these wallbreakers can pressure Cryogonal and Articuno for Shaymin while benefitting from its good matchups against Lanturn and Regirock. Pivots like Mesprit and Clawitzer can give Shaymin free switches to hit the field and conserve its health as it wallbreaks, which is especially useful if Shaymin forgoes recovery. Fire-types like Charizard and Typhlosion are major obstacles for Shaymin and can exploit its Choice item lock, so Shaymin benefits from partners like Regirock and Lanturn that can switch into Fire-types. Shaymin depends on Poison-resistant Pokemon like Sandslash and Sandaconda to mitigate its difficult matchups against Poison-types like Muk and Hisuian Sneasel. Special walls like Snorlax and Muk are vulnerable to Spikes, which can by set by Orthworm, and Shaymin can threaten Sandslash for Orthworm so that it doesn't have to have its Leftovers removed.

Whimsicott.overview: Blessed with the rare Fairy typing and an excellent Speed tier, Whimsicott makes for an excellent revenge killer and utility Pokemon. Whimsicott's unique typing allows it to beat many dangerous threats like Persian-Alola and Virizion. A powerful Moonblast and pivoting coupled with Choice Specs allow Whimsicott to break past bulkier threats like Orthworm and Glastrier. However, Whimsicott's low offensive stats leave it often wanting for power, especially without Choice Specs, and it's incapable of fitting every move it wants. Furthermore, lack of reliable recovery and only average bulk makes it unable to consistently check the Pokemon it's supposed to like Regirock and Sandaconda.
Whimsicott.comments:
Other Options

Psychic is an option that nails Poison-types like Weezing. However, this comes at the cost of either losing U-turn's pivoting or the utility of Switcheroo or Encore. Whimsicott can use a SubSeed set to mess up its usual defensive checks like Snorlax and Orthworm and be a general nuisance. This set struggles to find setup opportunities however and relies heavily on getting a free Substitute on a forced switch.

Checks and Counters

Poison-types: Whimsicott's 4x weakness to Poison and inability to hit Poison-types with its STAB attacks makes Poison-types like Muk and Weezing good checks. However, these Pokemon lack reliable recovery and can thus be worn down over a game.

Steel-types: Steel-types like Magneton and Orthworm can take Whimsicott's STAB attacks with ease. Orthworm can start setting entry hazards or set up with Coil or Iron Defense, while Magneton can generate momentum with Volt Switch.

Fire-types: As Whimsicott's STAB attacks do little to them, Fire-types like Charizard, Typhlosion, and Magmortar can use Whimsicott as an entry point to start firing off powerful attacks. These Pokemon aren't usually defensively invested however and can struggle to switch in consistently.

Special Walls: Special walls like Snorlax and Articuno aren't bothered by Whimsicott's attacks and can use it to start forcing progress with entry hazards, status, pivoting, or boosts. However, Switcheroo completely ruins these walls, especially Articuno, and Encore can force them to repeat their status moves, allowing Whimsicott to safely bring in a teammate.

Choice Scarf Users: Many common Choice Scarf users like Hisuian Sneasel and Gunk Shot Passimian get the jump on Whimsicott and can easily take it out.

Choice Specs.description:
Choice Specs Whimsicott takes advantage of its high Speed and Moonblast to be a powerful cleaner and revenge killer. U-turn lets It scout for switches and pivot out of unfavorable matchups like Weezing and Orthworm, allowing it to bring in a more suitable teammate. Switcheroo allows Whimsicott to cripple its defensive checks, greatly hindering special walls like Orthworm and especially Articuno, letting Whimsicott and its teammates break past them later in the game. However, Whimsicott loses a substantial amount of power without its Choice Specs, so one must be careful about when to use Switcheroo. Infiltrator allows Whimsicott to bypass Substitute from foes like Glastrier and opposing Whimsicott.

Choice Specs Whimsicott best fits on balance and bulky offense teams looking for a fast offensive cleaner that also provides some defensive utility. Whimsicott loves entry-hazard stacking teammates like Sandslash and Orthworm to help push its otherwise average damage output. It can't handle Fire-types like Charizard and Typhlosion, so answers to them like Regirock and Snorlax help immensely. Whimsicott can in return take advantage of the Grass- and Fighting-types like Virizion and Passimian that these Pokemon are at a disadvantage against. Whimsicott struggles with Poison-types like Weezing and Muk who resist its STAB attacks and threathen it with 4x super effective attacks, so answers like Magneton and Sandaconda make for great teammates. Whimsicott pairs well with offensive Fire-types like Typhlosion and Charizard that handle the Steel-types like Orthworm that it has difficulties breaking past, and in return, it handles their Water and Rock-type answers such as Regirock and Lanturn. Special sweepers such as Oricorio-F and Mesprit enjoy pairing with Whimsicott for its capability to pressure and cripple special walls like Snorlax and Lanturn.

Offensive Pivot.description:
Whimsicott leverages its superb Speed and access to Prankster to be a competent offensive pivot. Giga Drain is used for its ability to give Whimsicott staying power in longer games. Encore is key to this set, allowing it to force defensive foes into unfavorable moves like Stealth Rock and Recover, as well as shutting down setup sweepers like Oricorio-F and Snorlax by locking them into their setup moves. U-turn pairs beautifully with Encore, scouting any forced switches and allowing Whimsicott to bring in powerful teammates like Glastrier and Typhlosion. Tera Steel gives Whimsicott an immunity to Poison-type attacks from Muk and Weezing, and a resistance to Flying-type attacks from Dodrio as well as Ice-type attacks from Sneasel in a pinch. However, this still leaves Whimsicott vulnerable to Fire-type attacks from Charizard and Typhlosion and makes it weak to Fighting, making it unable to reliably switch into Passimian and Virizion. Tera Fire provides emergency resistances to Ice and Fire, but this makes Whimsicott unable to safely check Ground- and Rock-types like Sandaconda and Regirock.

Balance teams enjoy Whimsicott's pivoting and Prankster Encore helping them deal with bulky defensive Pokemon and dangerous setup sweepers. Powerful physical wallbreakers like Glastrier and Passimian pair well with Whimsicott, as it baits in special walls like Articuno and can bring these teammates in with U-turn. Ground-types like Sandaconda make for excellent partners, as Whimsicott helps them handle the Water- and Grass-types like Clawitzer and Virizion that they struggle with, while they can handle Poison-types like Muk that scare Whimsicott out. Fire-types like Charizard and Magmortar can easily gain entry on Whimsicott, so Fire-resistant teammates like Regirock, Naclstack, and Snorlax are helpful partners. Partners such as Charizard or Passimian that threaten Steel-types like Orthworm and Magneton can come in after a U-turn on these Steel-types to fire off attacks. Electric-types like Jolteon and Magneton appreciate Whimsicott's ability to handle Ground-types like Sandaconda, and in return, they handle the Flying-types like Dodrio and Articuno that Whimsicott struggles to beat. Other offensive pivots like Passimian and Mesprit can form a powerful VoltTurn core with Whimsicott, quickly racking up damage against walls like Regirock and Snorlax, especially with entry hazards up.

Beartic.overview: Under snow, Beartic is a chillingly threatening sweeper, boasting wide coverage and frightening offensive power while outspeeding the entire unboosted metagame. The Defense boost in snow allows it to tank physical attacks like Passimian's Close Combat and Lycanroc's Stone Edge. Beartic relies on Abomasnow to provide snow, and it forms a deadly offensive core with it, as Abomasnow's Aurora Veil makes Beartic even more difficult to take down. Beartic, however, is hindered by its low Speed and awful defensive typing; even under snow, it can be outsped by faster Choice Scarf users like Hisuian Sneasel and Typhlosion. Even with the Defense boost and Aurora Veil support, Beartic sports minimal defensive utility, owing to its vulnerability to all residual damage and lack of resistances if not running Heavy-Duty Boots, and it also stacks weaknesses with Abomasnow. Outside of snow, Beartic is extremely slow and easy to revenge kill without Terastallization, requiring significant support to perform well as a setup sweeper.
Beartic.comments:
Other Options

Beartic has no other viable options.

Checks and Counters

Faster Revenge Killers: Even under snow, Beartic is still quite slow and can be picked off by Choice Scarf users like Rotom-C, Hisuian Sneasel, and Shaymin.

Physical Walls: Physical walls like Weezing, Spiritomb, and Sableye can threaten Beartic with Will-O-Wisp, while walls like Regirock and Orthworm can beat it with Iron Defense in a one-on-one scenario.

Residual Damage: Beartic is vulnerable to all entry hazards if not running Heavy-Duty Boots and despises status, all of which heavily cut into its sweeping potential and making it easier to revenge kill.

Wallbreakers: Most wallbreakers not weak to its coverage moves can stomach at least one unboosted attack and retaliate, which is especially prominent if Beartic is not under snow. Examples include Passimian, Vikavolt, and Clawitzer.

Glastrier: Glastrier can leverage its massive bulk under snow and retaliate with its own coverage moves to defeat Beartic.

Snow Sweeper.description:
The combination of snow and Slush Rush enables Beartic to become one of the scariest setup sweepers under this archetype, boasting high offensive stats and outspeeding the entire unboosted metagame. Icicle Spear's higher power is preferred over Icicle Crash's potential flinch chance if running Loaded Dice, and its multiple hits work well against foes using Substitute like Minior, Mismagius, and Rotom-C. Close Combat threatens Ice-resistant targets like Snorlax, Orthworm, and Glastrier while also hitting Regirock hard. Earthquake threatens Lanturn, Magneton, and non-Choice Scarf Typhlosion, while Substitute capitalizes on weak walls like Snorlax and Dipplin. While an Adamant nature is ideal to maximize its power, Jolly can be used to outspeed Choice Scarf Passimian and Choice Scarf Mesprit under snow. If Beartic is not running Icicle Spear, Life Orb or Heavy-Duty Boots can be chosen to either strengthen all of its moves' power or protect it from entry hazard damage, respectively. Tera Fighting boosts the power of Close Combat and lets Beartic resist priority moves like Sucker Punch and Accelerock, while Tera Ground boosts the power of Earthquake and provides it a Stealth Rock resistance and Electric immunity while still resisting Accelerock; changing into either of these Tera types, however, relinquishes the Defense boost under snow.

Due to Beartic being heavily reliant on snow for wallbreaking, Abomasnow is a mandatory partner to enable Slush Rush and the Defense boost. Pivots like Clawitzer and Passimian can help threaten and force out walls like Regirock and Orthworm, while wallbreakers like Clawitzer and Charizard can be similarly effective. Hattrem is a notable partner, as it supplies paralysis and Healing Wish support, enabling Beartic to clean through teams easier, while providing Magic Bounce support for Beartic's non-Heavy-Duty Boots sets. Spinners like Sandslash and Hitmontop are also valuable partners, providing entry hazard removal support without needing to remove Aurora Veil. Water-types like Clawitzer and Lanturn can not only force out Fire-types but also provide pivoting support. Hazard setters like Regirock and Sandslash not only can help rack up residual damage over the course of a game but also provide additional utility with Thunder Wave and Knock Off, respectively. Other setup sweepers like Minior can overwhelm teams and shared checks like Regirock with Beartic.

Virizion.overview: Virizion's great Speed tier and threatening offensive typing make it a dangerous offensive threat that can serve as both a wallbreaker and a late-game cleaner. Virizion has access to Swords Dance, which allows it to boost its attack and wallbreak consistently. Its great Speed tier lets it stay threatening versus offensive teams and even clean them up late-game when its checks are weakened or removed. Virizion has naturally high special bulk and a workable defensive typing that allow it to find set up opportunities versus Choice-locked special attackers like Jolteon, Magneton, and Clawitzer, and there is some ambiguity to its sets thanks to its good coverage and ability to run a physical or special set. However, Virizion isn't especially strong without a boost, and it can struggle to break through physically bulky checks like Weezing and Dipplin. Despite that, Virizion retains a very solid niche thanks to its higher Speed tier and its ability to run coverage options like Stone Edge and Zen Headbutt.
Virizion.comments:
Other Options

Virizion can run a Tera Flying Calm Mind set using Giga Drain, Air Slash, and Focus Blast or Aura Sphere. This turns the tables on many of Virizion's traditional answers such as Dipplin and Weezing, and Virizion's STAB combination threatens several common special walls, such as Lanturn and Snorlax. However, Virizion can only boost its Special Attack by one stage at a time with Calm Mind, and it is forced to use weak moves unless it opts for the inaccurate Focus Blast as its Fighting-type STAB move, which makes the set considerably less threatening in practice. A mixed attacker set with Leaf Storm, Close Combat, Stone Edge, and Synthesis with a Life Orb can be threatening to certain offensive and balance teams but fails to make significant progress versus builds packing common walls such as Dipplin, Mesprit, and Muk. Sacred Sword is an interesting alternative to Close Combat that ignores the Defense boosts on IronPress foes such as Regirock, Orthworm, and Naclstack and doesn't lower Virizion's own defenses, but the drop in power is very noticeable. Tera Fairy is a fringe alternative Tera type that gives Virizion a Fighting resistance, allowing it to stave off revenge killing from Choice Scarf Passimian, and an immunity to Dragon Tail, which lets it potentially break past Dipplin after accruing multiple Swords Dance boosts. Tera Poison grants Virizion a generally useful defensive typing to counteract revenge killing attempts from the likes of Whimsicott and Passimian. These are inferior to the other Tera types outside of these specific situations, however.

Checks and Counters

Dipplin: Dipplin's massive physical bulk allows it to handily deal with the standard Swords Dance set. It isn't even 2HKOed by a +2 Close Combat and can use Dragon Tail to phaze Virizion before healing off any damage, which makes it a very reliable answer. It has to be wary of a surprise Calm Mind set, however, and the rare Tera Fairy can turn it into setup fodder.

Poison-types: Bulky Poison-types such as Weezing and Muk resist Virizion's STAB moves and threaten it in return with their STAB moves, or in Weezing's case, a burn from Will-O-Wisp. They must be cautious of Zen Headbutt, however. Hisuian Sneasel is faster than Virizion and can OHKO it with Gunk Shot. Additionally, several Pokemon that Virizion usually threatens, such as Sandslash and Regirock, commonly run Tera Poison and can therefore turn the tables on it.

Revenge Killers: Virizion's Speed tier, while very solid, still leaves it outpaced by several common revenge killers. Choice Scarf Passimian, Whimsicott, Sneasel, and Choice Scarf Typhlosion all outrun Virizion and can threaten to revenge kill it. All but the latter two need chip damage dealt before they can KO Virizion, however, and only Whimsicott and Passimian can directly switch in.

Status: Burns and paralysis are especially threatening to Virizion. Common Pokemon such as Weezing, Lanturn, and Charizard are all capable of spreading those status conditions, and Virizion is not capable of OHKOing any of them except for Charizard if it chooses to run Stone Edge. However, Lum Berry allows Virizion to circumvent this and set up on many of these foes fearlessly.

Swords Dance.description:
Swords Dance allows Virizion to break through bulky foes like Mesprit and Regirock. Stone Edge lets Virizion threaten Charizard, Articuno, and Oricorio-F. Zen Headbutt can be used instead to threaten Poison-types like Weezing and Muk. Justified dissuades foes such as Passimian and Poliwrath from attempting to remove Virizion's item via Knock Off. Heavy-Duty Boots allows Virizion to come in multiple times throughout a game without fear of chip damage from entry hazards. However, Lum Berry is a viable alternative on offensive teams, as it allows Virizion to set up safely on foes that might try to cripple it with status, such as Mesprit, Rotom, and Sandaconda. Tera Rock allows Stone Edge to OHKO Whimsicott and 2HKO Weezing after Stealth Rock damage at +2. It also gives Virizion a resistance to Fire- and Flying-type attacks, which lets it deal with Charizard, Typhlosion, and Oricorio-F with more confidence. Tera Psychic lets Zen Headbutt 2HKO Tera Poison Regirock at +2, do significantly more damage to Weezing, removes Virizion's weakness to their Poison-type STAB moves, and gives Virizion a useful Fighting resistance that can foil revenge killing attempts from Choice Scarf Passimian and opposing Virizion.

Virizion's great Speed tier and ability to both wallbreak and sweep depending on the situation make it usable on teams ranging from balanced to hyper offensive team styles. Virizion dislikes facing down extremely bulky physical walls such as Dipplin and Weezing and Iron Defense Pokemon such as Regirock and Orthworm, which can also outlast Virizion should they begin boosting as it comes in. Strong special attackers, such as Nasty Plot Mesprit, Magneton, and Charizard, are therefore good teammates; the former is especially good at disrupting these extremely bulky threats.
